attributes.description:
Below are a summary of 5 relevant papers and what they implied about this relationship.

Paper number 0
Opinion from: Childhood Maltreatment Was Correlated With the Decreased Cortical Function in Depressed Patients Under Social Stress in a Working Memory Task: A Pilot Study
Paper DOI <link>: 10.3389/fpsyt.2021.671574
Opinion extracted: inverse
Original user opinion: -
Supporting text used in extraction: In our pilot study, MDD patients had reduced brain activation, affecting emotional stimuli processing function, executive function, and cognitive control function. Childhood maltreatment might affect brain function in MDD.

Paper number 1
Opinion from: Cognitive Impairments in Unipolar Depression: The Impact of Rumination
Paper DOI <link>: 10.1159/000478785
Opinion extracted: direct
Original user opinion: -
Supporting text used in extraction: Resource allocation theory posits that rumination absorbs cognitive capacities which can thus not be directed towards task-relevant processes. Valuable cognitive resources are allocated to irrelevant depressive and ruminative thought processes.

Paper number 2
Opinion from: Effect of rejection sensitivity on the development of anxious-depressive attack in Japanese outpatients: The mediating roles of rumination, social anxiety, and depressive symptoms
Paper DOI <link>: 10.3389/fpsyg.2022.1016879
Opinion extracted: direct
Original user opinion: -
Supporting text used in extraction: Cognitive distraction is linked to a decrease in rumination.

Paper number 3
Opinion from: Cognitive deficits in patients with chronic fatigue syndrome compared to those with major depressive disorder and healthy controls
Paper DOI <link>: 10.1016/j.clineuro.2010.12.002
Opinion extracted: Direct
Original user opinion: -
Supporting text used in extraction: We evaluated the cognitive performance of patients with CFS using standardized verbal and visual memory tests, as well as sustained attention, working memory, and episodic memory. Our results showed that patients with CFS had slower phasic alertness and impaired working, visual, and verbal episodic memory compared to controls.

Paper number 4
Opinion from: Improvement in self-reported cognitive functioning but not in rumination following online working memory training in a two-year follow-up study of remitted major depressive disorder
Paper DOI <link>: 10.3389/fpsyt.2023.1163073
Opinion extracted: direct
Original user opinion: -
Supporting text used in extraction: Results suggested lasting improvements in self-reported cognitive functioning following online CWMT.

Below are a summary of 3 relevant papers and what they implied about this relationship.

Paper number 0
Opinion from: Cognitive Impairments in Unipolar Depression: The Impact of Rumination
Paper DOI <link>: 10.1159/000478785
Opinion extracted: direct
Original user opinion: +
Supporting text used in extraction: Rumination is a style of thinking characterized by repetitive, recurrent, intrusive, and uncontrollable thoughts. People who ruminate repetitively contemplate reasons for and consequences of their sadness.

Paper number 1
Opinion from: Effect of rejection sensitivity on the development of anxious-depressive attack in Japanese outpatients: The mediating roles of rumination, social anxiety, and depressive symptoms
Paper DOI <link>: 10.3389/fpsyg.2022.1016879
Opinion extracted: direct
Original user opinion: +
Supporting text used in extraction: Rumination is positively associated with sadness.

Paper number 2
Opinion from: Improvement in self-reported cognitive functioning but not in rumination following online working memory training in a two-year follow-up study of remitted major depressive disorder
Paper DOI <link>: 10.3389/fpsyt.2023.1163073
Opinion extracted: direct
Original user opinion: +
Supporting text used in extraction: Rumination is an emotion regulation strategy where one passively broods over self-related negative experiences.

Below are a summary of 3 relevant papers and what they implied about this relationship.

Paper number 0
Opinion from: Cognitive Impairments in Unipolar Depression: The Impact of Rumination
Paper DOI <link>: 10.1159/000478785
Opinion extracted: not applicable
Original user opinion: -
Supporting text used in extraction: The text does not provide any information or evidence regarding the relationship between rumination and RSA withdrawal.

Paper number 1
Opinion from: Effect of rejection sensitivity on the development of anxious-depressive attack in Japanese outpatients: The mediating roles of rumination, social anxiety, and depressive symptoms
Paper DOI <link>: 10.3389/fpsyg.2022.1016879
Opinion extracted: direct
Original user opinion: -
Supporting text used in extraction: Rumination is linked to an increase in RSA withdrawal.

Paper number 2
Opinion from: Improvement in self-reported cognitive functioning but not in rumination following online working memory training in a two-year follow-up study of remitted major depressive disorder
Paper DOI <link>: 10.3389/fpsyt.2023.1163073
Opinion extracted: uncorrelated
Original user opinion: -
Supporting text used in extraction: Results are mixed regarding whether interventions like CWMT improve rumination.

Opinion from: Effect of rejection sensitivity on the development of anxious-depressive attack in Japanese outpatients: The mediating roles of rumination, social anxiety, and depressive symptoms
Paper DOI <link>: 10.3389/fpsyg.2022.1016879
Opinion extracted: direct
Original user opinion: +
Supporting text used in extraction: Forced-failure stress has been shown to lead to RSA withdrawal.
